Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of Structure and Electron Transport in Porphyrin and Phthalocyanine Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professors Ursula Mazur and K. W. Hipps of Washington State University are supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program in the Division of Chemistry to conduct research that employs a combination of experimental and synthetic methods for studying the molecular and submolecular scale chemical, electronic, and material properties of porphyrin and phthalocyanine nanostructured aggregates. The overall goal of the proposed research is to attain an in depth understanding of: (1) the driving forces behind molecular ordering, dimensions, and morphology in the nanostructures, (2) the nature of electronic communication between the molecules comprising different aggregate structures, and (3) the impact of (1) and (2) on the conductivity (transverse and longitudinal) of aggregates in contact with a metallic surface under different environmental conditions.

The proposed research provides new insights about the structural and electronic changes associated with the formation of nanostructures from electroactive organic monomers. A fundamental understanding of the morphology-structure-function relationships enables rational design of nanostructures for a particular electronic, photonic, or sensing application. The results from this research would impact several important areas of modern technology, including chemical and light sensors, photocells, catalysis, and molecular electronics. This project provides an exceptional training environment for students (graduate, undergraduate, and high school) by integrating cutting-edge nanoscale energy related research with training in scientific integrity, teamwork, and leadership.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of the current grant we conducted new fundamental experimental and computational studies at the micrometer, nanometer, and molecular scale of the chemical, physical, electronic, and structural properties of metal-free porphyrin multidimensional nanostructured self-assemblies fabricated from charged monomers. These assemblies are a novel class of porphyrin based nanomaterials that may serve as efficient light-harvesting components for dye-sensitized solar cells and organic photovoltaics. We identified the molecular ordering in these eletroactive aggregates, their growth, and their mechanical and photophysical properties. Our focus was on correlating the structure–property relationship of the porphyrin nanostructures.

Using oppositely charged porphyrins we produced micro and nano size crystalline rods and needles and, in some cases, hyperbranched assemblies. To obtain comprehensive information about the internal structure and intermolecular interactions of the ionic tectons within the solid assemblies we employed a battery of microscopic and spectroscopic techniques complemented by calculations (DFT) and modeling. Our experimental and theoretical data support an arrangement of alternating positively and negatively charged macrocycles forming columns along the length of the nanostructures.  Ionic bonding, hydrogen bonding, and p-p interactions each contribute to aligning the tectons in cofacially packed columns.

The nanostructures have band gaps of about 2 eV, are conducting, photoconducting, and also exhibit persistent photoconductivity. We are the first to measure and report the mechanical properties of porphyrin nanostructures. Young's Modulus values acquired from some nanostructures (using AFM) are comparable the modulus for organic polymers. This is a remarkable result because the porphyrin nanostructures posses no intermolecular covalent bonds as in the case of polymers. We have developed the first model that successfully simulates the growth of organic crystalline porphyrin materials as a function of growth temperature and concentration. The growth of the multidimensional structures was modeled using classical crystallization theories including nucleation, growth, and Ostwald ripening.

Our research provides new insights about the structural, mechanical, and electronic changes associated with the formation of nanostructures from electroactive organic monomers. A fundamental understanding of the morphology-structure-mechanics-function relationships will enable a rational design of nanostructures for a particular electronic, photonic, or sensing application. The results from this research impact several important areas of modern technology, including chemical and light sensors, photocells, catalysis, and molecular electronics.


Last Modified: 10/05/2015
Modified by: Kerry W Hipps
